Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF An Automated Search for Deep Tremor and its Relationship to the Seismic Cycle in Southern California
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Justin Brown has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at California Institute of Technology. This project aims to improve our understanding of the earthquake cycle by applying newly developed, high resolution methods. Recent analyses of continuous seismic waveform data allowed seismologists to discover a new class of seismic signals on faults that host large subduction earthquakes named non-volcanic tremors. This newly identified signal has been shown to comprise repeating low-frequency earthquakes that occur in both temporal and spatial patterns throughout the seismic cycle. In addition, recent studies have shown that non-volcanic tremor can be triggered by surface waves of large earthquakes at remote distances. Previous investigations have identified tremor in limited regions in southern California, but a comprehensive effort to detect and catalog non-volcanic tremor in southern California has not yet been done. This project will utilize waveform cross-correlation techniques to characterize non-volcanic tremor in southern California in context of the seismic cycle. Dr. Brown will search systematically for tremor and determine the recurrence intervals of low frequency earthquakes. Investigations and central cataloging of tremor in southern California will provide new insights into the nature of seismogenic faults and earthquake source physics.

This project also includes a middle school Earth sciences outreach program. The program has three goals: 1) To introduce young students from underrepresented minorities to the Earth sciences; 2) To help prepare young people for natural disasters in their communities; and 3) To expose students to cutting-edge research regardless of their background. This program will take place over the course of two years and will include monthly field trips, outdoor activities and community-based service projects led by students themselves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Tectonic tremor, composed of repeating swarms of low-frequency earthquakes (LFEs), is a long duration low amplitude signal proven difficult to detect. In this study, I demonstrated tests to accurately discern ambient LFEs/tremor from local earthquakes and cultural noise in southern California. The work presented here is aimed to 1) Present that new phenomena of slow earthquakes occur on the San Jacinto Fault Zone and 2) Show tests of tremor/LFE detection that should be applied in places where tremors/LFEs have not been previously reported.

 

Ambient tectonic tremor is a long-duration low amplitude signal depleted in frequencies over 10 Hz. Shown at left are four examples of ambient tremor in subduction zones (SW Japan, Cascadia, Costa Rica and the Aleutian Arc. Tremor is also observed in strike slip systems. At right is 70 minutes of tremor recorded near Cholame in central California along the San Andreas fault.

 

The San Jacinto Fault Zone

The San Jacinto Fault Zone (SJFZ) is an active transform feature in southern California. It is the most active strand of the southern San Andreas fault (SAF) system. The fault zone has has smaller maximum earthquake magnitudes compared to the SAF. This area is ideal to search for long-duration signals on account of the enhanced seismic monitoring.

 

In this study, I found using local transportation authority data that ~100 trains travel throughout the neighboring Coachella Valley everyday in both roughly northwest and southeast directions. The train traffic can look like tremor. Aftershock sequences include many repeating earthquakes which makes event identification cumbersome. It is cumbersome for autocorrelation techniques (Brown et al., 2008), smoothed waveform envelope correlation techniques (following Wech and Creager, 2008), and back projection techniques (following Ghosh et al., 2009)- all of have which have been tested in this area in the last five years. With that said, more creative ways must be developed to understand tremor in this area with enhanced monitoring. The aforementioned methods were tested in tandem to reveal less than robust results for location of the source.

 

In conclusion, observationally challenging environments such as southern California can lend themselves to to a negative result. Nonetheless, this provides a ripe opportunity for scientisits to develop new approaches to understanding low amplitude tremor in various tectonic environments posing the same challenge. My suggestion is to deploy several small aperature arrays (~20km radius) at varying distances from the fault zone of interest, using the same methods aforementioned in tandem, and contacting the investigators with experience in the area such as myself to collaborate on such endeavors in addition to "thinking outside the box" for new methods.

As outlined in the original research proposal, a negative result in this case is actually a positive result in order to further the science. I plan to continue work in this area in my future research endeavors.
